instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.WS_KBD_ONOFF_L: What is WS_KBD_ONOFF_L? WS_KBD_ONOFF_L is a signal that comes from the keyboard that tells the SMC that the power button has been pressed.  L means whatever before the L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v. This signal directly affects SMC_ONOFF_L.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 2012 15 inch <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No power button
threads.message:
A customer sent in his MacBook for repair. No water damage at all. resistor <RESISTOR>R5710</RESISTOR> was not showing any continuity, I replaced the pin and it shows continuity. however, there's still no power button functionality.
 Note- the keyboard is now stuck in caps for some reason :/

threads.title: MacBook Pro 2012 15 inch <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No power button
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Do you have <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board there?
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>WS_KBD_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> when you press power button.
Test using <RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR>/16 pads instead of power button.

If <RESISTOR>R5710</RESISTOR> was corroded, remove <CAPACITOR>C5710</CAPACITOR>, which can be affected too.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 2012 15 inch <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No power button
threads.message:
Thank you 2informatics!!

So while doing that, what should i be looking for when i short those pads?

threads.message: The mentioned pads simulate power button...
